erf 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Extreme predictions with a quantile forest

Source: R/extremeForest_deprecated.R
predict_erf.Rd

Predicts high conditional quantiles of Y given X using a quantile forest fitted using quantile_forest.

predict_erf(
  object,
  quantiles = c(0.95, 0.99),
  threshold = 0.8,
  newdata = NULL,
  model_assessment = FALSE,
  Y.test = NULL,
  out_of_bag = FALSE,
  param_est = c("ML", "Hill"),
  lambda = 0
)

Arguments

object

Quantile forest object. The trained forest obtained with quantile_forest.

quantiles

Numeric vector (0, 1). Extreme quantiles at which estimates are required. Default is quantiles = c(0.95, 0.99).

threshold

Numeric (0, 1). Intermediate quantile used to compute thresholds \(t(x_i)\) for the GPD. Note that threshold < quantiles. Default is 0.8.

newdata

Numeric matrix. Rows contain observation at which predictions should be made. If NULL, makes out-of-bag predictions on the training set instead (i.e., provides predictions at Xi using only trees that did not use the i-th training example). Note that this matrix should have the number of columns as the training matrix, and that the columns must appear in the same order. This argument is needed if model_assessment = TRUE. Default is NULL.

model_assessment

Boolean. Assess GPD fit with QQ-plot against exponential distribution? Default is FALSE.

Y.test

Numeric vector. Responses for the test set, needed if model_assessment = TRUE. Default is NULL.

out_of_bag

Boolean. Use out-of-bag observations to compute thresholds \(t(x_i)\) for the GPD? Default is FALSE.

param_est

Character. One of "ML" and "Hill". Specifies the method to fit the shape and scale parameter of the GDP distribution. "ML" is the weighted maximum likelihood approach proposed by Terefe et al. (2020) . "Hill" is the weighted Hill's estimator approach proposed by Deuber (2020) . Default is "ML".

lambda

Numeric (>= 0). Penalty coefficient for the \(\xi\) parameter in the weighted log-likelihood, i.e., when param_est = "ML". Default is 0.

Value

Named list. The list is made of:

  • predictions --- Numeric matrix. Predictions at each test point (on rows) for each desired quantile (on columns).

  • pars --- Numeric matrix. Estimated parameters at each test point (on rows). The columns contain the estimates for the \(\sigma\) and \(\xi\) parameter, respectively.

  • threshold --- Numeric matrix. Intermediate thresholds at each test point (on rows), estimated using quantile_forest.

  • plot (if model_assessment = TRUE). QQ-plot for model assessment.

References

Deuber D (2020). “A Quantile Extrapolation Approach for Extreme Quantile Treatment Effect Estimation.” arXiv preprint arXiv:_._.

Terefe EM, Gnecco N, Engelke S (2020). “Extreme Random Forests.” arXiv preprint arXiv:_._.

Contents
